title: How to identify a classical music piece - Quora

response.answer_text: As opposed to? Do you mean “how do I identify that it is classical” or “how do I identify the composer/name of a classical piece?” I suspect you are asking the latter. If so, the only way is to have a lot of exposure to classical music of all eras. First you should focus on identifying the era or style (medieval, baroque, impressionism, atonal, romantic etc.) Once you can differentiate Debussy from Dowland, and Puccini from Purcell, and Bruch from Bach (tell me to stop), more listening will help you to identify major works, and finally, you should be able to name the era without knowing the composer (someone who sounds like Vivaldi but isn’t). Being able to identify an era/style is the real skill. You can’t memorize every piece written, so you have to recognize styles. Contrapuntal vs. not contrapuntal, etc.

There’s nothing like experience in making such judgements, and the matter of whether a piece is “classical” or “early romantic’ is not of critical importance in listening and enjoying. However, a couple of easy places to begin. You will learn to recognize the balance and regular phraseology in ‘classical’ music, and in piano, the Alberti Bass, C-G-E-G. C-G-E-G in the accompaniment. Doesn’t alway happen, but it’s a tendency. In an orchestra, double woodwinds: 2 flutes, 2 clarinets, 2 oboes, 2 bassoons, 2 horns, 2 trumpets, two timpani and no additional percussion—that’s ‘classical.’. Any ‘funny instrument,’ English Horn, Piccolo, Trombones, Tuba, Bass Clarinet, Contra-Bassoon—these imply later music, mid-romantic period probably. Cymbals, Bass Drum, Triangle—all occur rarely in ‘Classical” music, anything more in percussion almost guarantees later music. There is a Mozart Opera which uses a keyboard glockenspiel, but xylophone or more than 2 timpani almost always rule out ‘classical’ music. If you hear a piano with cymbals (seriously) that was the rage in the ‘classical’ period, Turkish Music, but you never hear it today. I’d like to. All of these considerations are minor fluff compared to ‘listening to the music,’ gaining the flavor of it, and witnessing clarity, balance, decorum, and restraint, the regular phrases, the elegance. Even early Beethoven piano sounds a bit ‘rustic’ to me, vigorous, and indelicate compared to Mozart, which sounds ‘proper,’ elegant, and slightly reserved. Mozart’s orchestra music sounds a bit restrained to me, maybe impersonal slightly—though I love Mozart, this is the flavor I get. But, as in any example of sophistication, of exquisite taste, or sophisticated judgement, experience is all! And that’s the fun of Classical (and Baroque and Romantic) music—even contemporary music!—listen, be surprised, hear the growth, love it all!

Do you mean in general, or is there a specific piece you want to know about? It helps a lot to know a little bit about music history, and what is called “active listening” - meaning you don’t listen to it as background music or distraction, but you focus on it and pay ateention to details - melodic theme, orchestration, structure, etc. In general, start by narrowing down the period and genre, per Chris’s answer below. It can require some detective work on your part, or ask someone you know who is into that style of music, that composer, that era. Trying to identify one specific piece of music can be a challenge if you don’t have much to go on, other than your own ears. That’s why even a one semester course in music history can be invaluable for anybody - it really helps a lot when you’re getting familiar with different kinds of music.

Listen to a great deal of it. Try to develop a musical memory. If you live in an area with a classical radio station you can listen to that, or you can listen on the internet on YouTube, etc. People recognize the pieces they are familiar with, so you need to listen and gain familiarity with the basic repertoire. Learn to listen for the various motifs or melodic shapes and what instruments are playing them. If you spend enough time listening and can also read musical notation and hear it in your mind, you can even get to the point of recognizing pieces you are familiar with just by looking at a page of the score.

It's always a fun game to play. Clearly, the more you listen to a variety of styles and composers, the better chance you have of identifying the particular piece. Each period of music has its own characteristics, and by listening carefully, you can ascertain what a Mozart piano concerto has in common with a Haydn symphony or a Scarlatti sonata, thus becoming fluent in aspects of the so-called classical style. Repeat for other genres.

Or, you could consult A Dictionary of Musical Themes (Barlow & Morgenstern). [My mom had a copy of this when I was a boy, and we used it frequently to look up (classical) themes we couldn’t quite put our finger on.] I don’t think it has been updated since 1950, although there may be more recent updates. There are also online resources that will give you the answers you are looking for. A Dictionary of Musical Themes - Barlow, Harold

Unless there is a descriptive title given, the music doesn’t mean anything. Most titles are just stating the form: Symphony, Sonata, Concerto, Gigue, Waltz, etc. The music doesn’t need a meaning beyond its own sound. On the other hand, a lot of music, especially getting into the Romantic period and beyond, is “program music” where there is definitely a meaning involved. But this is shown in the title: “A Hero’s Life”, “Resurrection Symphony”, “Petroushka”, “The Hours”, “Saturday In The Park”, etc. (Ok, that last one is not classical, but you get the idea.)

“Is there an easy way for remembering what a piece of classical music is called?” Not really. Unless you are a music major or music professional, or it’s a very famous piece, most people just remember the composer and what type of piece it was. So you might remember “ it was a Beethoven piano sonata” but unless it’s the famous Moonlight sonata you probably won’t remember more than that. But if you have a good aural memory you often only need listen to a brief passage to remember if it’s the one you’re thinking of. A few classical pieces have been given names to help us remember them. Mozart’s “Jupiter” symphony for example.
